text: They follow the service road skirting the river.
They stay on the hardpack, turbines receding behind them.
They leave the road and take a maintenance path into fir and alder.
Light thins. They step onto a narrow trail under low branches.
The grade steepens across broken rock; they climb in short, even bursts.
The path drops into a draw; leaf litter slides underfoot.
They wade a cold braid of the river, boots tied by their laces.
In the dark, the water presses at their knees; they cross in silence.
Somewhere upslope, something moves when they move; then stops.
A clatter from the scree makes them freeze, then listen.
Cloud cover thickens; flashlights cut narrow cones between trees.
Sun finds gaps in the cloud; the path brightens in patches.
The air still smells metallic, as if the dam were inside the forest.
Two arrows on the same post point opposite directions.
They greet a traveler who later passes them again, from the wrong direction.
Rain starts and stops within a minute. A second front is coming.
They smell bread and smoke where no houses stand.
Lanterns sway from low branches, lit from no source they can see.
Music without origin drifts over the creek.
The tunnel exhales; air draws them toward the dark.
Jane names the stones; Jill repeats the names until they feel right.
White shapes stand in a grove. They do not touch them.
They are matched step for step. When they stop, it stops.
A presence keeps pace just out of sight.
They enter a clearing that shouldn’t exist; every path looks new.
Footing goes, but a trunk holds. They breathe until the shake passes.
A friendly voice points to a shortcut that loops back on itself.
They check their packs and the compass is gone.
A trader wants too much for a hint. They walk on.
Footsteps grow closer on the road; they run until breath burns.
A windfall blocks the way; they crawl and pass packs across.
They cross a spillway grate one by one, each step sounding hollow.
A sign reads: “Do not speak while the bridge is crossed.”
A boulder too round for this valley sits squarely on the trail.
A child asks a question that isn’t a question. They answer with a nod.
Without lights, they count steps and turns; the dark equals them.
A name that worked earlier fails; they try another.
The river here is black and fast; they cross in silence.
At a fork, a survey marker points east. They mark the map and continue.
Fresh paint on an old post shows an arrow where none had been.
Jill reconstructs the creek bends from memory; they correct course.
An old woman offers a pebble “for finding your way back.” They keep it.
Under a flat stone, someone left a biscuit wrapped in paper.
A white moth waits at the tunnel mouth, wings like a small flag.
“Keep left at the fork,” a man under the bridge says.
They tape a frayed strap and change socks.
They split an apple and drink from the thermos.
They redistribute weight between the packs and set off again.
They go a stretch without speaking, counting breaths.
A joke from earlier lands wrong; they let it go.
They estimate four more kilometers since the dam.
They agree not to enter any building with a second story.
They repeat the names for the turns until the names feel right.
The path repeats three rises and a bend; they trust it.
They shoulder their packs and check the map. The road runs east along the river.
They leave the access road beyond the fence line. The plant hum fades behind them.
A lane appears between trees. They walk the last hundred meters without a word.
